column3: is a branch of fluid dynamics concerned with studying the motion of air
column4: particularly when it interacts with a solid object
column5: such as an airplane wing. Aerodynamics is a sub-field of fluid dynamics and gas dynamics
column6: and many aspects of aerodynamics theory are common to these fields. The term aerodynamics is often used synonymously with gas dynamics
column7: with the difference being that "gas dynamics" applies to the study of the motion of all gases
column8: not limited to air. Formal aerodynamics study in the modern sense began in the eighteenth century
column9: although observations of fundamental concepts such as aerodynamic drag have been recorded much earlier. Most of the early efforts in aerodynamics worked towards achieving heavier-than-air flight
column10: which was first demonstrated by Wilbur and Orville Wright in 1903. Since then
column11: the use of aerodynamics through mathematical analysis
column14: and computer simulations has formed the scientific basis for ongoing developments in heavier-than-air flight and a number of other technologies.
